properties.Title: Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory For The Unorganized Hamlet Of Lac Vert
properties.Summary:
Description: A Precautionary Drinking Water Advisory has been issued for the Unorganized Hamlet of Lac Vert. This advisory is for the Unorganized Hamlet of Lac Vert and for any individuals who may access water from the Unorganized Hamlet of Lac Vert water system. This advisory is in effect until further notice.
Expires: 2019-04-12T12:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Annaheim, 2019-04-08T08:27:43-06:00, 9B00F8EF-3510-96FE-CD40-2BB90C9C199B
Area: Unorganized Hamlet of Lac Vert.
properties.Author: SK Annaheim

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow will continue tonight with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm expected before ending in the morning. Snowfall warnings continue for southwestern regions of the province, where total accumulations up to 20 cm are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Total snowfall amounts of 15 centimetres is expected on Tuesday. This snow will bring additional weight on structures and trees already covered in freezing precipitation. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Another blast of winter weather today. Precipitation associated with a fast moving low pressure system will move into Eastern Ontario this morning. Snow at times heavy is expected for areas close to the Quebec border, with snowfall accumulations of 10 to 15 cm possible by later this afternoon. There is also a risk of brief freezing rain and ice pellets. Motorists are advised to exercise caution today. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-09T13:26:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-09T05:27:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2649299270.2019
Area: Gatineau, Deep River - Whitney - Eastern Algonquin Park, Prescott and Russell, Petawawa - Pembroke - Cobden, Barry's Bay - Killaloe, Renfrew - Arnprior - Calabogie, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orléans
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Snow mixed with freezing drizzle will continue until early this morning with total snowfall amounts near 15 cm expected. Another system is expected to bring 5 to 10 centimetres of snow Tuesday night. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-09T11:59:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-09T05:21:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0390697717.2019
Area: Fredericton and Southern York County, Oromocto and Sunbury County, Grand Lake and Queens County, Sussex - Kennebecasis Valley and Kings County, Saint John and County, Fundy National Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Periods of snow are forecast to become heavy at times early Tuesday morning. Accumulations near 25 cm are expected by Wednesday morning. Fresh snow will combine with strong northerly winds gusting near 70 km/h to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow overnight tonight and Tuesday. Visibility along the coast may improve briefly Tuesday afternoon as temperatures rise to near zero, but is then expected to deteriorate again in the evening. Poor visibility and snowfall may continue through Wednesday into Thursday. However, at this time snowfall accumulations for Wednesday and Thursday do not appear to be significant. The public is advised to monitor this alert for updates on when conditions will improve. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-09T19:25:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-09T03:26:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2241227007.2019
Area: Postville - Makkovik
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Fresh snowfall and strong northerly winds gusting up to 80 km/h will combine to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow on Tuesday. Conditions are expected to persist into Wednesday for most areas. However, northernmost regions may see an improvement as early as Tuesday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-04-09T19:25:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-09T03:26:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3852571601.2019
Area: Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Snow will continue tonight before ending in the morning with total snowfall amounts near 15 cm expected. A second system approaching from the west will bring further accumulations of snow on Tuesday night and Wednesday. Amounts near 5 cm are currently forecast for Tuesday night, with higher amounts possible in some areas. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-09T14:09:24-00:00

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions developed this afternoon. Falling snow with wind gusts to 60 km/h will continue to reduce visibilities to 400 m or less until late this evening when snowfall begins to taper off. Wind speeds are not expected to drop significantly until Tuesday morning so blowing snow may persist through the night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2019-04-09T06:00:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-04-08T23:23:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3292430915.2019
Area: Gjoa Haven
properties.Author: Environment Canada
